messages: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:40): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: FWIW, we're trying to make the DOM run on constructors instead of factory functions.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:41): Um, OK. In what way?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:41): In that "new HTMLPElement()" should work, and be subclassable.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:42): You are planning to expose this to web content?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:42): Larry Masinter suggests using Wikipedia for registries over on www-tag
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:42): Interesting‚Ä¶
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:42): wfm
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:42): Once we get it working, yes.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:42): new HTMLMediaElement("div") -> ?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:42): Or do you have one interface per element?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:42): The latter, presumably.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:42): s/interface/constructor/
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:43): This is still in a handwavey stage in terms of details.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:43): But we're poking at V8 to see how we can do this and allow subclassing like a normal JS object.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:43): While still wiring up the appropriate binding magic on the back-end.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:44): subclassing === function MyP(){}; MyP.prototype = HTMLPElement?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:44): (I see no reason not to use established terminology just because we use a different model of OO.)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:45): So, obviosuly I like the idea, but why are you doing this?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:45): Because factory functions are ugly, and DOM objects aren't subclassable.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:45): (This ties into the component model stuff we're doing.)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:45): (the inheritance thing seems like it might encourage dubious design patterns like putting custom functions on built-in objects)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: That'd work until someone deletes the registry because it's original research
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:50): This is, of course, what the microformats wiki is for.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:53): there's a lot of registries
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:53): I doubt microformats would want to host URL schemes
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:54): Ask tantek.  He's been sanguine about it before, I believe.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:07): How do you create an SVG image with just an aspect ratio, not an intrinsic width/height?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:10): only setting viewBox="" ?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:10): or is the intrinsic width/height 100%/100% then?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:10): Is that how you do it?  I don't understand the relationship between width/height/viewBox.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:10): I had a hard time figuring that out in the SVG spec last time I played with all that
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:12): I failed last time I tried. img { width:90%; } solved my problem, though.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:13): That doesn't help when you're using SVG in list-style-image.

7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:17): Hixie, is ‚ÄúThe message's content type was not explicitly allowed‚Äù referring to application/pgp-signature attachments or a sniffing error on part of the web server? (fun fact: the message contained the string SRT)

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:18): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Okay, you're right.  You can leave width/height alone and just set a viewbox to establish a coordinate system, then use one of the uniform-scaling preserveAspectRatio values.
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (18:21): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e got it right
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:21): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: Yup, got it.  Was just making sure I was right before I corrected a dude.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:23): I wonder where I left my tests for this

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:24): Ugh, I hate talking to Alan Gresley.  The dude runs a css tutorial site, but he is usually *completely* wrong about everything.  Somehow he manages to form a uniquely wrong understanding of technical topics that I care about.
